text:
Madison Avenue, east side, south from 27th Street, showing the second Madison Square Garden, 1889-1925. Beyond it, on S.E. corner of 26th Street, is the University Club of New York, which occupied this building from about 1883 to 1900. The building, originally the Lawrence Jerome residence, still stands (1935), the home of the Manhattan Club. On S.E. corner of 24th Street is old Madison Square Presbyterian Church, a brownstone structure with steeplel 1854
1895.
August Loeffler, Photographer.
From P.L. Sperr collection.

Madison Avenue, East Side and East 24th Street at the South East corner, this Church was replaced by the Metropolitan Tower. The church was organized in 1853.

About 1900

No Record.

General View: Madison Square.
Madison Square Garden Looking in a northeasterly direct on from about 24th Street, towards Madison Avenue east side and the Garden.

Charles Ritzman
No reproduction.
1900.

(1)
Madison Square, southwestern portion, looking northeast across the park at the tower of Madison Square Garden. In the foreground is the statue of William H. Seward, from a design by Randolph Rogers; and at the right is the brownstone steeple of the Madison Square Presbyterian Church (1854-1906), Madison Avenue at S. E. corner of 24th Street. Dr. Charles Parkhurst was pastor of this church, and from its pulpit launched his famous attack on Tammany Hall which drove Croker into exile, and swept a reform administration into power. To the right of the Church is the Metropolitan Life Building, whose expansion will destroy this church and its successor, built on the N. E.
corner.
About 1905.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2)
The same at a later date. Note the additional large buildings on the 24th to 25th Streets block. These in 1937 were demolished by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company which at this date utilizes two
square blocks for their office structures.

1916.

Nicholas Savostayanoff.
Gift of George D. Chinn.

(1)

Seward, from a design by Randolph Rogers; and at the right is the brownstone steeple of the Madison Square Presbyterian Church (1854-1906), Madison Avenue at S. E. corner of 24th Street. Dr. Charles Parkhurst was pastor of this church, and from its pulpit launched his famous attack on Tammany Hall which drove Croker into exile, and swept a reform administration into power. To the right of the Church is the Metropolitan Life Building, whose expansion will destroy this church and its successor, built on the N. E.
corner.
About 1905.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2)

square blocks for their office structures.

1916.

Nicholas Savostayanoff.
Gift of George D. Chinn.

Madison Square and East 24th Street on North East corner, showing the Madison Square Presbyterian Church at 1906 and 1914, later demolished and removed Stanford White was the Architect.

E.M. Jenks Photog.
January 24, 1905.

Madison Avenue, at the N. E. corner of East 24th Street, showing the Stanford White designed, Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church under construction. This was eventually removed for an office structure affiliated with the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company though church facilities were accorded therein. Subsequently a block-wide project for the same people will necessitate
removal. Dr. Parkhurst was a minister here.
View 2 is a photo of the Hartford (Conn.) Times showing there
the pillars of the church.
View 1: 1906
View 2: July 1932
George L. Balgue
2: NEG~R E680

Madison Avenue, at the N. E. corner of East 24th Street, showing the Stanford White designed, Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church under construction. This was eventually removed for an office structure affiliated with the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company though church facilities were accorded therein. Subsequently a block-wide project for the same people will necessitate
removal. Dr. Parkhurst was a minister here.
View 2 is a photo of the Hartford (Conn.) Times showing there
the pillars of the church.
View 1: 1906
View 2: July 1932
George L. Balgue
2: NEG~R E680

Madison Square Presbyterian Church, Madison Avenue at N. E. corner of 24th Street, built by Hokis, Head & White from designs by Stanford White, and dedicated on October 14, 1906. It succeeded a brownstone steepled Church which stood on the S.E. corner and was then being removed to make room for the Metropolitan Life Insurance Building Tower.
The new church was demolished in 1919 and gave place to the Metropolitan Annex (1920). The Corinthian columns across the front of the church were sent to Hartford, Conn; and from part of the facade of the new building of the Hartford Times. Two small buildings to left of church were erected about 1913.
1918-1919
Ewing Galloway, Photographer

Wrecking the Madison Square Presbyterian Church, Madison Avenue, at the N.E. corner of 24th Street, to make way for the Metropolitan Life Insurance Annex.

1919.

Gift of E. M. Jenks.

(1)

Madison Ave., east side, from 24th to 26th Streets, seen across Madison Square from 23rd Street and Broadway. On the N.E. corner of 24th Street stands the Metropolitan Annex, which in 1920 replaced the Madison Square Presbyterian Church. The other buildings in that block date back at most to 1911. Trees hide the small houses in the next block, so that the next visible building is the New York Life Insurance Building on the N.E. corner of 26th Street, on the site of the old Garden.

About 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

The same, at a later date. The three buildings shown in the center of the view, from right to left, beginning with the one that has the white sign on it, are; the 15-story Pullman Building (No. 17 Madison Ave.); the 14-story Farragut Building (No. 19); and the 20-story Madison Ave. Building (No. 21-25), south of, adjoining and at the S.E. corner of East 25th Street. These three buildings are shown in the process of being dismantled internally, and will be completely razed, in what is considered one of the largest demolition operations undertaken in years, and is being carried out by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Co., which owns the property. No plans have been made for the immediate improvement of the land.

June 9, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)

Madison Ave., east side, from 24th to 26th Streets, seen across Madison Square from 23rd Street and Broadway. On the N.E. corner of 24th Street stands the Metropolitan Annex, which in 1920 replaced the Madison Square Presbyterian Church. The other buildings in that block date back at most to 1911. Trees hide the small houses in the next block, so that the next visible building is the New York Life Insurance Building on the N.E. corner of 26th Street, on the site of the old Garden.

About 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

The same, at a later date. The three buildings shown in the center of the view, from right to left, beginning with the one that has the white sign on it, are; the 15-story Pullman Building (No. 17 Madison Ave.); the 14-story Farragut Building (No. 19); and the 20-story Madison Ave. Building (No. 21-25), south of, adjoining and at the S.E. corner of East 25th Street. These three buildings are shown in the process of being dismantled internally, and will be completely razed, in what is considered one of the largest demolition operations undertaken in years, and is being carried out by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Co., which owns the property. No plans have been made for the immediate improvement of the land.

June 9, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Madison Ave., east side, from 24th to 25th Streets, seen across Madison Square from Fifth Ave.

September 23, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, at a later date. This view shows the 20-story Madison Ave. Building (No. 21-25); the Farragut Building (No. 19); and the 15-story Pullman Building, at, adjoining and south of the S.E. corner of East 25th Street in the process of being dismantled internally. They will be completely razed in what is considered to be one of the largest demolition operations to be undertaken in years. It is being carried out by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Co., owners of the entire block of property, which includes the 16-story Metropolitan Life Annex Building, at the N.W. corner of East 24th Street (right). In a release issued by the Metropolitan, it states that no plans are being made for the immediate improvement of the land, but that it is being cleared for future use. This view is taken from Fifth Ave., and across Madison Square Park.

June 9, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The same, showing a more comprehensive view of Madison Square Park.

June 9, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Madison Ave., east side, from 24th to 25th Streets, seen across Madison Square from Fifth Ave.

September 23, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, at a later date. This view shows the 20-story Madison Ave. Building (No. 21-25); the Farragut Building (No. 19); and the 15-story Pullman Building, at, adjoining and south of the S.E. corner of East 25th Street in the process of being dismantled internally. They will be completely razed in what is considered to be one of the largest demolition operations to be undertaken in years. It is being carried out by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Co., owners of the entire block of property, which includes the 16-story Metropolitan Life Annex Building, at the N.W. corner of East 24th Street (right). In a release issued by the Metropolitan, it states that no plans are being made for the immediate improvement of the land, but that it is being cleared for future use. This view is taken from Fifth Ave., and across Madison Square Park.

June 9, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The same, showing a more comprehensive view of Madison Square Park.

June 9, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)

Madison Ave., 25th to 24th Street, from N.W. corner of Broadway and 25th Street. Note Metropolitan Life tower on right, not quite all in picture.

September 23, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

The same, at a later date. The 20-story Madison Ave. Building (No. 21-25); the 14-story Farragut Building (No. 19); and the 15-story Pullman Building (No. 17), at, adjoining and south of the S.E. corner of East 25th Street are seen being dismantled internally, in what is considered to be one of the largest demolition operations in years. This is being carried out by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, owners of the entire block of property, which includes the 16-story Metropolitan Life Annex Building (No. 11-15), visible at the N.E. corner of East 24th Street (right). The Metropolitan Life Insurance Co., according to a statement issued by it, does not plan to improve the land at present, but is clearing it for future use. This view is taken from Broadway and across Fifth Ave. and Madison Square Park.

June 9, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)

The same, another view, as seen from Fifth Ave.
June 9, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)

Madison Ave., 25th to 24th Street, from N.W. corner of Broadway and 25th Street. Note Metropolitan Life tower on right, not quite all in picture.

September 23, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

The same, at a later date. The 20-story Madison Ave. Building (No. 21-25); the 14-story Farragut Building (No. 19); and the 15-story Pullman Building (No. 17), at, adjoining and south of the S.E. corner of East 25th Street are seen being dismantled internally, in what is considered to be one of the largest demolition operations in years. This is being carried out by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, owners of the entire block of property, which includes the 16-story Metropolitan Life Annex Building (No. 11-15), visible at the N.E. corner of East 24th Street (right). The Metropolitan Life Insurance Co., according to a statement issued by it, does not plan to improve the land at present, but is clearing it for future use. This view is taken from Broadway and across Fifth Ave. and Madison Square Park.

June 9, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)

The same, another view, as seen from Fifth Ave.
June 9, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

Madison Ave., at the S.E. corner of East 24th Street; the Metropolitan Insurance Co. tower of 50-stories, as viewed in a southwestward direction from a roof top at Lexington Ave. and East 28th Street.

February 22, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

Madison Avenue, at E. 24th Street, showing the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company tower at the S.E. corner of that location. The photographer is viewing southeastward across the corner of Madison Square Park formed by Fifth Avenue (right foreground) and E. 26th Street (left foreground). This, geographically, is the S.E. corner.

June 5, 1933

P. L. Sperr

Madison Ave., north from and including East 24th Street, showing scaffolding erected in front of three tall buildings, Nos. 17, 19, and 21-25, south of, adjoining and at the S.E. corner of East 25th Street, in preparation for their demolition, an operation which is being conducted by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Co. On the west side of the street (left) is visible part of Madison Square Park as it extends north to East 26th Street. Also shown (left center) are Nos. 27 to 15 East 26th Street, at, adjoining and west of the N.W. corner of Madison Ave., with the tower of the Empire State Building appearing in the background. June 9, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

Madison Ave., (buildings thereon) east side, between East 24th (right) and 25th (left) Streets, showing units of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company towering above a clearance at the S.E. corner of 25th Street and upon which will rise another edifice to this Company's enterprise. This view is photographed in an eastward direction from Fifth Ave., and across Madison Square Park.

November 9, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

Madison Ave., (buildings thereon) east side, from East 24th (right) to 25th Streets, as viewed eastward from Fifth Ave. and across Madison Square. Shown under demolition are buildings at the S.E. corner of East 25th Street. For data upon same, see other views. No. 2 of this set of views is southeastward from 26th Street.

July 22, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

Madison Ave., (buildings thereon) east side, from East 24th (right) to 25th Streets, as viewed eastward from Fifth Ave. and across Madison Square. Shown under demolition are buildings at the S.E. corner of East 25th Street. For data upon same, see other views. No. 2 of this set of views is southeastward from 26th Street.

July 22, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

Madison Ave., east side, north from East 24th to 27th Streets, showing at the N.E. corner of East 25th Street the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, as viewed across a clearance at the S.E. corner (former site of the Madison Ave. Building and others).

November 9, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

Madison Avenue, east side, at East 24th Street, as viewed eastward from across Madison Square Park. Shown at the location given are the several structures of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. The older unit with its tower is at the S. E. corner. The 1920 annex (with flag atop) is at the N. E. corner. This is shortly to go and its site included in the block square project shown partially completed at the S. E. corner of East 25th Street.

September 27, 1940
No's. 1-2

P. L. Sperr

Madison Avenue, east side, at East 24th Street, as viewed eastward from across Madison Square Park. Shown at the location given are the several structures of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. The older unit with its tower is at the S. E. corner. The 1920 annex (with flag atop) is at the N. E. corner. This is shortly to go and its site included in the block square project shown partially completed at the S. E. corner of East 25th Street.

September 27, 1940
No's. 1-2

P. L. Sperr

Church

Dr. Parkhursts new church and old church at Madison Ave. & 24th St.
